oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blythe Ferry: history and property survey
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shadden Rd. at Tennessee River, Birchwood, Meigs County, TN
This history and property description of Blythe Ferry also includes a table, “Cherokee Detachments Who Crossed the Tennessee River at Blythe Ferry.”

Blythe Ferry, one of Tennessee's most important Trail of Tears landmarks, is located on the Tennessee River between Meigs and Rhea Counties. William Blythe, a mixed-ancestry Native American, began operating the ferry on the Federal Road in 1809. Following Blythe’s death in 1856, the ferry passed through several hands before being replaced by a bridge in 1994. The historical ferry landings now lie under the waters of the Chickamauga impoundment. The Cherokee Removal Memorial Park has been constructed at the site.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cherokee Indians -- 1830-1840; Cherokee Indians -- Relocation; Ferries;
